entries.text: joris joris presents us a small utility script  mashing the functionality of the venerable 'head' and 'grep' tools together.
entries.title: headgrep : keep the head, and grep the rest

entries.author: joel_berger
entries.text: A new CMS system hits the shelves, Joel Berger announces. Galileo is very simple, and very pretty. But don't take my word for it, give it a whirl!
entries.title: Galileo 0.012 released!

entries.author: vyacheslav_matyukhin
entries.text: A new file locking module enters the CPAN fray: Vyacheslav Matyukhin's Lock::File.
entries.title: Lock::File - yet another file locking module

entries.author: toby_inkster
entries.text: Toby Inkster introduces 'Ask', a new module that does its darnedest to interact with the user. No interactive prompt? I'll try to use Tk, Wx, Gtk2 or even zenity widgets to get its questions across. And it's meant to be easily extended, so that if everything else fails, you can still write your own ESP plugin.
entries.title: Ask not what your user can do for you...

entries.text: Here comes some serious competition for Acme::Magic::Pony. Nicholas Perez introduces CloudPAN, which makes installing (pure perl) modules on local machines a thing of the past.
entries.title: CloudPAN

entries.author: john_napiorkowski
entries.text: The aftermaths of Stevan Little's talk at the Orlando Perl Workshop continue to be felt.  Here, it's John Napiorkowski's turn to muse on what was said, and what it means for the future.
entries.title: Worth a Consideration

entries.text: With the "Perl's a Dead-End" wails still ringing in our ears, Adam Taylor muses what we have to offer to attract new blood, beside echo chambers filled with zombies. And raptors.
entries.title: Encouraging newcomers to stick with Perl

entries.text: If you want to do it, Rob Hammond provides instructions how to make it happen.
entries.title: Running a Mojolicious non-lite app on a cPanel VPS server

entries.text: Yanick re-heats some Perl Advent leftovers and revisits the Dancer megasplat operator.
entries.title: Dancer Goes Megasplat

entries.text: I tell you HTTP requests and you immediatly think GET and POST, and perhaps PUT, DELETE and all the rest of the REST gang. But what about poor HEAD?  Sebastian reminds us about these oft-forgotten requests.
entries.title: Where is your HEAD?

entries.author: tokuhiro_matsuno
entries.text: Straight-up question, to which tokuhirom provides a straight-up answer.
entries.title: How can I install all favorited distributions from CPAN?

entries.text: Anonymous functions are a handy way to wrap code, but hardly the only one. chromatic shows us one of the alternatives.
entries.title: Wrapping Existing Code without Anonymous Functions

entries.author: dan_wright
entries.text: Interested in the financial details of the Perl Foundation? Dan Wright has the numbers for you.
entries.title: Perl 5 Core Maintenance Fund Status

entries.text: Wherein a NQP frontend is plugged into a QAST to JVM backend. Which is a good thing. ... I think.
entries.title: A quick JVM backend update

header: Howdie, Yanick speaking here. Gabor is out on a well-deserved vacation, and left me the keys of the PerlWeekly. The fool.
subject: Heads in the Cloud
